member.name: T:NTwain.Data.TWDecodeFunction
member.summary: Embedded in the structure that is embedded in the structure. Defines the parameters used for channel-specific transformation. The transform can be described either as an extended form of the gamma function or as a table look-up with linear interpolation.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWDecodeFunction.StartIn
member.summary: Starting input value of the extended gamma function. Defines the minimum input value of channel data.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWDecodeFunction.BreakIn
member.summary: Ending input value of the extended gamma function. Defines the maximum input value of channel data.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWDecodeFunction.EndIn
member.summary: The input value at which the transform switches from linear transformation/interpolation to gamma transformation.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWDecodeFunction.StartOut
member.summary: Starting output value of the extended gamma function. Defines the minimum output value of channel data.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWDecodeFunction.BreakOut
member.summary: Ending output value of the extended gamma function. Defines the maximum output value of channel data.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWDecodeFunction.EndOut
member.summary: The output value at which the transform switches from linear transformation/interpolation to gamma transformation.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWDecodeFunction.Gamma
member.summary: Constant value. The exponential used in the gamma function.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWDecodeFunction.SampleCount
member.summary: The number of samples in the look-up table. Includes the values of StartIn and EndIn. Zero-based index (actually, number of samples - 1). If zero, use extended gamma, otherwise use table look-up.

member.name: T:NTwain.Data.TWElement8
member.summary: Embedded in the , , and structures. This structure holds the tri-stimulus color palette information for structures. The order of the channels shall match their alphabetic representation. That is, for RGB data, R shall be channel 1. For CMY data, C shall be channel 1. This allows the application and Source to maintain consistency. Grayscale data will have the same values entered in all three channels.

member.summary: Second tri-stimulus value (e.g Green).

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWInfo.Item
member.summary: Contains either data or a handle to data. The field contains data if the total amount of data is less than or equal to four bytes. The field contains a handle if the total amount of data is more than four bytes. The amount of data is determined by multiplying NumItems times the byte size of the data type specified by ItemType. If the Item field contains a handle to data, then the Application is responsible for freeing that memory.

member.name: T:NTwain.Data.TWExtImageInfo
member.summary: This structure is used to pass extended image information from the data source to application at the end of State 7. The application creates this structure at the end of State 7, when it receives XFERDONE. Application fills NumInfos for Number information it needs, and array of extended information attributes in Info[ ] array. Application, then, sends it down to the source using the above operation triplet. The data source then examines each Info, and fills the rest of data with information allocating memory when necessary.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWExtImageInfo.Info

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWIdentity.DataGroup
member.summary: Gets the supported data group. The application will normally set this field to specify which Data Group(s) it wants the Source Manager to sort Sources by when presenting the Select Source dialog, or returning a list of available Sources.

member.summary: Major number of latest TWAIN version that this element supports.

member.summary: A structure identifying the TWAIN entity.

member.summary: Tells an application that performs device-specific operations which product family the Source supports. This is useful when a new Source has been released and the application doesn't know about the particular Source but still wants to perform Custom operations with it. e.g. "ScanMan".

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWIdentity.ProductName
member.summary: A string uniquely identifying the Source. This is the string that will be displayed to the user at Source select-time. This string must uniquely identify your Source for the user, and should identify the application unambiguously for Sources that care. e.g. "ScanJet IIc".

member.name: T:NTwain.Data.TWImageInfo
member.summary: Describes the "real" image data, that is, the complete image being transferred between the Source and application. The Source may transfer the data in a different format--the information may be transferred in "strips" or "tiles" in either compressed or uncompressed form.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageInfo.XResolution
member.summary: The number of pixels per ICapUnits in the horizontal direction. The current unit is assumed to be "inches" unless it has been otherwise negotiated between the application and Source.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageInfo.YResolution
member.summary: The number of pixels per ICapUnits in the vertical direction.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageInfo.ImageWidth
member.summary: How wide, in pixels, the entire image to be transferred is. If the Source doesn’t know, set this field to -1 (hand scanners may do this).

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageInfo.ImageLength
member.summary: How tall/long, in pixels, the image to be transferred is. If the Source doesn’t know, set this field to -1 (hand scanners may do this).

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageInfo.SamplesPerPixel
member.summary: The number of samples being returned. For R-G-B, this field would be set to 3. For C-M-Y-K, 4. For Grayscale or Black and White, 1.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageInfo.BitsPerSample
member.summary: For each sample, the number of bits of information. 24-bit R-G-B will typically have 8 bits of information in each sample (8+8+8). Some 8-bit color is sampled at 3 bits Red, 3 bits Green, and 2 bits Blue. Such a scheme would put 3, 3, and 2 into the first 3 elements of this array. The supplied array allows up to 8 samples. Samples are not limited to 8 bits. However, both the application and Source must simultaneously support sample sizes greater than 8 bits per color.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageInfo.BitsPerPixel
member.summary: The number of bits in each image pixel (or bit depth). This value is invariant across the image. 24-bit R-G-B has BitsPerPixel = 24. 40-bit CMYK has BitsPerPixel=40. 8-bit Grayscale has BitsPerPixel = 8. Black and White has BitsPerPixel = 1.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageInfo.Planar
member.summary: If SamplesPerPixel > 1, indicates whether the samples follow one another on a pixel-by-pixel basis (R-G-B-R-G-B-R-G-B...) as is common with a one-pass scanner or all the pixels for each sample are grouped together (complete group of R, complete group of G, complete group of B) as is common with a three-pass scanner. If the pixel-by-pixel method (also known as "chunky") is used, the Source should set Planar = FALSE. If the grouped method (also called "planar") is used, the Source should set Planar = TRUE.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageInfo.PixelType
member.summary: This is the highest categorization for how the data being transferred should be interpreted by the application. This is how the application can tell if the data is Black and White, Grayscale, or Color. Currently, the only color type defined is "tri-stimulus", or color described by three characteristics. Most popular color description methods use tristimulus descriptors. For simplicity, the constant used to identify tristimulus color is called Rgb, for R-G-B color. There is no default for this value.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageInfo.Compression
member.summary: The compression method used to process the data being transferred. Default is no compression.

member.name: T:NTwain.Data.TWImageLayout
member.summary:
Involves information about the original size of the acquired image and its position on the original "page" relative to the "page’s" upper-left corner. Default measurements are in inches (units of measure can be changed by negotiating the ICapUnits capability). This information may be used by the application to relate the acquired (and perhaps processed image) to the original. Further, the application can, using this structure, set the size of the image it wants acquired.
Another attribute of this structure is the included frame, page, and document indexing information. Most Sources and applications, at least at first, will likely set all these fields to one. For Sources that can acquire more than one frame from a page in a single acquisition, the FrameNumber field will be handy. Sources that can acquire more than one page from a document feeder will use PageNumber and DocumentNumber. These fields will be especially useful for forms-processing applications and other applications with similar document tracking requirements.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageLayout.Frame
member.summary: Frame coords within larger document.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageLayout.DocumentNumber
member.summary: The document number, assigned by the Source, that the acquired data originated on. Useful for grouping pages together. Initial value is 1. Increment when a new document is placed into the document feeder (usually tell this has happened when the feeder empties). Reset when no longer acquiring from the feeder.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageLayout.PageNumber
member.summary: The page which the acquired data was captured from. Useful for grouping Frames together that are in some way related. Initial value is 1. Increment for each page fed from a page feeder. Reset when a new document is placed into the feeder.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageLayout.FrameNumber
member.summary: Usually a chronological index of the acquired frame. These frames are related to one another in some way; usually they were acquired from the same page. The Source assigns these values. Initial value is 1. Reset when a new page is acquired from.

member.name: T:NTwain.Data.TWMemory
member.summary: Provides information for managing memory buffers. Memory for transfer buffers is allocated by the application--the Source is asked to fill these buffers. This structure keeps straight which entity is responsible for deallocation.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWMemory.Flags
member.summary: Encodes which entity releases the buffer and how the buffer is referenced.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWMemory.Length
member.summary: The size of the buffer in bytes. Should always be an even number and wordaligned.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWMemory.TheMem
member.summary: Reference to the buffer. May be a Pointer or a Handle (see Flags field to make this determination).

member.name: T:NTwain.Data.TWImageMemXfer
member.summary: Describes the form of the acquired data being passed from the Source to the application in memory transfer mode.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageMemXfer.Compression
member.summary: The compression method used to process the data being transferred.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageMemXfer.BytesPerRow
member.summary: The number of uncompressed bytes in each row of the piece of the image being described in this buffer.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageMemXfer.Columns
member.summary: The number of uncompressed columns (in pixels) in this buffer.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageMemXfer.Rows
member.summary: The number or uncompressed rows (in pixels) in this buffer.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageMemXfer.XOffset
member.summary: How far, in pixels, the left edge of the piece of the image being described by this structure is inset from the "left" side of the original image. If the Source is transferring in "strips", this value will equal zero. If the Source is transferring in "tiles", this value will often be non-zero.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageMemXfer.YOffset
member.summary: Same idea as XOffset, but the measure is in pixels from the "top" of the original image to the upper edge of this piece.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageMemXfer.BytesWritten
member.summary: The number of bytes written into the transfer buffer. This field must always be filled in correctly, whether compressed or uncompressed data is being transferred.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWImageMemXfer.Memory
member.summary: A structure of type describing who must dispose of the buffer, the actual size of the buffer, in bytes, and where the buffer is located in memory.

member.name: T:NTwain.Data.TWJpegCompression
member.summary: Describes the information necessary to transfer a JPEG-compressed image during a buffered transfer. Images compressed in this fashion will be compatible with the JPEG File Interchange Format, version 1.1.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWJpegCompression.ColorSpace
member.summary: Defines the color space in which the compressed components are stored.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWJpegCompression.Subsampling
member.summary: Encodes the horizontal and vertical subsampling in the form ABCDEFGH, where ABCD are the high-order four nibbles which represent the horizontal subsampling and EFGH are the low-order four nibbles which represent the vertical subsampling. Each nibble may have a value of 0, 1, 2, 3, or 4. However, max(A,B,C,D) * max(E,F,G,H) must be less than or equal to 10. Subsampling is irrelevant for single component images. Therefore, the corresponding nibbles should be set to 1. e.g. To indicate subsampling two Y for each U and V in a YUV space image, where the same subsampling occurs in both horizontal and vertical axes, this field would hold 0x21102110. For a grayscale image, this field would hold 0x10001000. A CMYK image could hold 0x11111111.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWJpegCompression.NumComponents
member.summary: Number of color components in the image to be compressed.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWJpegCompression.RestartFrequency
member.summary: Number of MDUs (Minimum Data Units) between restart markers. Default is 0, indicating that no restart markers are used. An MDU is defined for interleaved data (i.e. R-G-B, Y-U-V, etc.) as a minimum complete set of 8x8 component blocks.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWJpegCompression.QuantMap
member.summary: Mapping of components to Quantization tables.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWJpegCompression.QuantTable
member.summary: Quantization tables.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWJpegCompression.HuffmanMap
member.summary: Mapping of components to Huffman tables. Null entries signify selection of the default tables.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWJpegCompression.HuffmanDC
member.summary: DC Huffman tables. Null entries signify selection of the default tables.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWJpegCompression.HuffmanAC
member.summary: AC Huffman tables. Null entries signify selection of the default tables.

member.name: T:NTwain.Data.TWRgbResponse
member.summary: This structure is used by the application to specify a set of mapping values to be applied to RGB color data. Use this structure for RGB data whose bit depth is up to, and including, 8-bits. The number of elements in the array is determined by —the number of elements is 2 raised to the power of .

member.summary: Transfer curve descriptors. To minimize color shift problems, writing the same values into each channel is desirable.

member.name: T:NTwain.Data.TWSetupFileXfer
member.summary: Describes the file format and file specification information for a transfer through a disk file.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWSetupFileXfer.FileName
member.summary: A complete file specifier to the target file. On Windows, be sure to include the complete pathname.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWSetupFileXfer.Format
member.summary: The format of the file the Source is to fill.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWSetupFileXfer.VRefNum
member.summary: The volume reference number for the file. This applies to Macintosh only. On Windows, fill the field with -1.

member.name: T:NTwain.Data.TWSetupMemXfer
member.summary: Provides the application information about the Source’s requirements and preferences regarding allocation of transfer buffer(s).

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWSetupMemXfer.MinBufferSize
member.summary: The size of the smallest transfer buffer, in bytes, that a Source can be successful with. This will typically be the number of bytes in an uncompressed row in the block to be transferred. An application should never allocate a buffer smaller than this.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWSetupMemXfer.MaxBufferSize
member.summary: The size of the largest transfer buffer, in bytes, that a Source can fill. If a Source can fill an arbitrarily large buffer, it might set this field to negative 1 to indicate this (a hand-held scanner might do this, depending on how long its cord is). Other Sources, such as frame grabbers, cannot fill a buffer larger than a certain size. Allocation of a transfer buffer larger than this value is wasteful.

member.name: P:NTwain.Data.TWSetupMemXfer.Preferred
member.summary: The size of the optimum transfer buffer, in bytes. A smart application will allocate transfer buffers of this size, if possible. Buffers of this size will optimize the Source’s performance. Sources should be careful to put reasonable values in this field. Buffers that are 10’s of kbytes will be easier for applications to allocate than buffers that are 100’s or 1000’s of kbytes.

Since only certain file formats support compression, this capability must be negotiated after setting the desired file format with ICAP_IMAGEFILEFORMAT. Corresponds to TWCP_* values.

member.name: T:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFO
member.summary: Defines the dimensions and color information for a DIB.

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFO.bmiHeader
member.summary: Structure that contains information about the dimensions of color format.

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFO.bmiColors
member.summary: This contains one of the following: 1. An array of RGBQUAD. The elements of the array that make up the color table. 2. An array of 16-bit unsigned integers that specifies indexes into the currently realized logical palette. This use of bmiColors is allowed for functions that use DIBs. The number of entries in the array depends on the values of the biBitCount and biClrUsed members of the BITMAPINFOHEADER structure.

member.name: T:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER
member.summary: Structure that contains information about the dimensions and color format of a DIB.

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biSize
member.summary: The number of bytes required by the structure.

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biWidth
member.summary: The width of the bitmap, in pixels. If Compression is JPEG or PNG, the Width member specifies the width of the decompressed JPEG or PNG image file, respectively.

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biHeight
member.summary: The height of the bitmap, in pixels. If Height is positive, the bitmap is a bottom-up DIB and its origin is the lower-left corner. If Height is negative, the bitmap is a top-down DIB and its origin is the upper-left corner. If Height is negative, indicating a top-down DIB, Compression must be either RGB or BITFIELDS. Top-down DIBs cannot be compressed. If Compression is JPEG or PNG, the Height member specifies the height of the decompressed JPEG or PNG image file, respectively.

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biPlanes
member.summary: The number of planes for the target device. This value must be set to 1.

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biBitCount
member.summary: The number of bits-per-pixel. The BitCount member determines the number of bits that define each pixel and the maximum number of colors in the bitmap.

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biCompression
member.summary: The type of compression for a compressed bottom-up bitmap (top-down DIBs cannot be compressed).

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biSizeImage
member.summary: The size, in bytes, of the image. This may be set to zero for RGB bitmaps. If Compression is JPEG or PNG, SizeImage indicates the size of the JPEG or PNG image buffer, respectively.

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biXPelsPerMeter
member.summary: The horizontal resolution, in pixels-per-meter, of the target device for the bitmap. An application can use this value to select a bitmap from a resource group that best matches the characteristics of the current device.

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biYPelsPerMeter
member.summary: The vertical resolution, in pixels-per-meter, of the target device for the bitmap.

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biClrUsed
member.summary: The number of color indexes in the color table that are actually used by the bitmap. If this value is zero, the bitmap uses the maximum number of colors corresponding to the value of the BitCount member for the compression mode specified by Compression.

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biClrImportant
member.summary: The number of color indexes that are required for displaying the bitmap. If this value is zero, all colors are required.

member.name: M:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.GetXDpi
member.summary: Gets the horizontal dpi of the bitmap.

member.name: M:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.GetYDpi
member.summary: Gets the vertical dpi of the bitmap.

member.name: M:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.GetByteSize
member.summary: Gets the size of the structure.

member.name: M:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.Validate
member.summary: Checks to see if this structure contain valid data. It also fills in any missing pieces if possible.

member.name: M:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.GetScan0(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Gets the pointer to scan0 given the header pointer.

member.summary: Gets whether the bitmap is bottom-up or top-down format.
member.value: true if this instance is bottom up image; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Gets the System.Drawing pixel format of current structure.

member.summary: Gets the color palette that's contained in the header. Note not all images will have palette, so check if the return value is null before using it.

member.name: M:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.GetStride
member.summary: Gets the stride size of this bitmap.

member.name: M:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.ToString
member.summary: Returns a that represents this instance.

member.name: T:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.CompressionType
member.summary: Indicates the bitmap compression of .

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.CompressionType.BI_RGB
member.summary: An uncompressed format.

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.CompressionType.BI_RLE8
member.summary: A run-length encoded (RLE) format for bitmaps with 8 bpp. The compression format is a 2-byte format consisting of a count byte followed by a byte containing a color index. For more information, see Bitmap Compression.

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.CompressionType.BI_RLE4
member.summary: An RLE, format for bitmaps with 4 bpp. The compression format is a 2-byte format consisting of a count byte followed by two word-length color indexes. For more information, see Bitmap Compression.

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.CompressionType.BI_BITFIELDS
member.summary: Specifies that the bitmap is not compressed and that the color table consists of three DWORD color masks that specify the red, green, and blue components of each pixel. This is valid when used with 16- and 32-bpp bitmaps.

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.CompressionType.BI_JPEG
member.summary: Indicates that the image is a JPEG image.

member.name: F:NTwain.Interop.BITMAPINFOHEADER.CompressionType.BI_PNG
member.summary: Indicates that the image is a PNG image.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.AudioNativeXfer.Get(System.IntPtr@)
member.summary: Causes the transfer of an audio data from the Source to the application, via the Native transfer mechanism, to begin. The resulting data is stored in main memory in a single block. The data is stored in AIFF format on the Macintosh and as a WAV format under Microsoft Windows. The size of the audio snippet that can be transferred is limited to the size of the memory block that can be allocated by the Source.

member.summary: This operation is used by the application to query the data source for its current settings, e.g. DPI, paper size, color format. The actual format of the data is data source dependent and not defined by TWAIN.

member.summary: This operation is used by the application to set the current settings for a data source to a previous state as defined by the data contained in the customData data structure. The actual format of the data is data source dependent and not defined by TWAIN.

member.name: T:NTwain.Triplets.DeviceEvent
member.summary: Represents .

member.name: T:NTwain.Triplets.EntryPoint
member.summary: Represents .

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.EntryPoint.Get(NTwain.Data.TWEntryPoint@)
member.summary: Gets the function entry points for twain 2.0 or higher.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.Event.ProcessEvent(NTwain.Data.TWEvent)
member.summary: This operation supports the distribution of events from the application to Sources so that the Source can maintain its user interface and return messages to the application. Once the application has enabled the Source, it must immediately begin sending to the Source all events that enter the application’s main event loop. This allows the Source to update its user interface in real-time and to return messages to the application which cause state transitions. Even if the application overrides the Source’s user interface, it must forward all events once the Source has been enabled. The Source will tell the application whether or not each event belongs to the Source.

member.name: T:NTwain.Triplets.FileSystem
member.summary: Represents .

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.FileSystem.AutomaticCaptureDirectory(NTwain.Data.TWFileSystem)
member.summary: This operation selects the destination directory within the Source (camera, storage, etc), where images captured using CapAutomaticCapture will be stored. This command only selects the destination directory (a file of type Directory). The directory must exist and be accessible to the Source. The creation of images within the directory is at the discretion of the Source, and may result in the creation of additional sub-directories.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.FileSystem.ChangeDirectory(NTwain.Data.TWFileSystem)
member.summary: This operation selects the current device within the Source (camera, storage, etc). If the device is a , then this command enters a directory that can contain files. If the device is a , then this command enters a directory that can contain files. If the device is a , then this command enters a directory that can contain or files.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.FileSystem.Copy(NTwain.Data.TWFileSystem)
member.summary: This operation copies a file or directory. Absolute and relative pathnames are supported. A file may not be overwritten with this command. If an Application wishes to do this, it must first delete the unwanted file and then reissue the Copy command. The Application specifies the path and name of the entry to be copied in InputName. The Application specifies the new patch and name in OutputName. It is not permitted to copy files into the root directory.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.FileSystem.CreateDirectory(NTwain.Data.TWFileSystem)
member.summary: This operation creates a new directory within the current directory. Pathnames are not allowed, only the name of the new directory can be specified.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.FileSystem.Delete(NTwain.Data.TWFileSystem)
member.summary: This operation deletes a file or directory on the device. Pathnames are not allowed, only the name of the file or directory to be deleted can be specified. Recursive deletion can be specified by setting the Recursive to TRUE.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.FileSystem.FormatMedia(NTwain.Data.TWFileSystem)
member.summary: This operation formats the specified storage. This operation destroys all images and subdirectories under the selected device. Use with caution.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.FileSystem.GetClose(NTwain.Data.TWFileSystem)
member.summary: The operation frees the Context field in fileSystem. Every call to GetFirstFile must be matched by a call to GetClose to release the Context field.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.FileSystem.GetFirstFile(NTwain.Data.TWFileSystem)
member.summary: This operation gets the first filename in a directory, and returns information about that file (the same information that can be retrieved with GetInfo).

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.FileSystem.GetInfo(NTwain.Data.TWFileSystem)
member.summary: This operation fills the information fields in fileSystem. InputName contains the absolute or relative path and filename of the requested file. OutputName returns the absolute path to the file.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.FileSystem.GetNextFile(NTwain.Data.TWFileSystem)
member.summary: This operation gets the next filename in a directory, and returns information about that file (the same information that can be retrieved with GetInfo).

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.FileSystem.Rename(NTwain.Data.TWFileSystem)
member.summary: This operation renames (and optionally moves) a file or directory. Absolute and relative path names are supported. A file may not be overwritten with this command. If an Application wishes to do this it must first delete the unwanted file, then issue the rename command. The Application specifies the path and name of the entry to be renamed in InputName. The Application specifies the new path and name in OutputName. Filenames in the root directory cannot be moved or renamed.

member.name: T:NTwain.Triplets.Identity
member.summary: Represents .

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.Identity.CloseDS
member.summary: When an application is finished with a Source, it must formally close the session between them using this operation. This is necessary in case the Source only supports connection with a single application (many desktop scanners will behave this way). A Source such as this cannot be accessed by other applications until its current session is terminated.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.Identity.GetDefault(NTwain.Data.TWIdentity@)
member.summary: Gets the identification information of the system default Source.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.Identity.GetFirst(NTwain.Data.TWIdentity@)
member.summary: The application may obtain the first Source that are currently available on the system which match the application’s supported groups.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.Identity.GetNext(NTwain.Data.TWIdentity@)
member.summary: The application may obtain the next Source that are currently available on the system which match the application’s supported groups.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.Identity.OpenDS(NTwain.DataSource)
member.summary: Loads the specified Source into main memory and causes its initialization.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.Identity.Set(NTwain.Data.TWIdentity)
member.summary: It allows an application to set the default TWAIN driver, which is reported back by GetDefault.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.Identity.UserSelect(NTwain.Data.TWIdentity@)
member.summary: This operation should be invoked when the user chooses Select Source... from the application’s File menu (or an equivalent user action). The Source selected becomes the system default Source.

member.name: T:NTwain.Triplets.Parent
member.summary: Represents .

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.Parent.CloseDsm(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: When the application has closed all the Sources it had previously opened, and is finished with the Source Manager (the application plans to initiate no other TWAIN sessions), it must close the Source Manager.
member.param: The handle. On Windows = points to the window handle (hWnd) that will act as the Source’s "parent". On Macintosh = should be a NULL value.

member.summary: Causes the Source Manager to initialize itself. This operation must be executed before any other operations will be accepted by the Source Manager.
member.param: The handle. On Windows = points to the window handle (hWnd) that will act as the Source’s "parent". On Macintosh = should be a NULL value.

member.name: T:NTwain.Triplets.PassThru
member.summary: Represents .

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.PassThru.PassThrough(NTwain.Data.TWPassThru)
member.summary: PASSTHRU is intended for the use of Source writers writing diagnostic applications. It allows raw communication with the currently selected device in the Source.

member.name: T:NTwain.Triplets.PendingXfers
member.summary: Represents .

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.PendingXfers.EndXfer(NTwain.Data.TWPendingXfers)
member.summary: This triplet is used to cancel or terminate a transfer. Issued in state 6, this triplet cancels the next pending transfer, discards the transfer data, and decrements the pending transfers count. In state 7, this triplet terminates the current transfer. If any data has not been transferred (this is only possible during a memory transfer) that data is discarded.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.PendingXfers.Get(NTwain.Data.TWPendingXfers)
member.summary: Returns the number of transfers the Source is ready to supply to the application, upon demand. If DAT_XFERGROUP is set to DG_Image, this is the number of images. If DAT_XFERGROUP is set to DG_AUDIO, this is the number of audio snippets for the current image. If there is no current image, this call must return Failure / SeqError.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.PendingXfers.Reset(NTwain.Data.TWPendingXfers)
member.summary: Sets the number of pending transfers in the Source to zero.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.PendingXfers.StopFeeder(NTwain.Data.TWPendingXfers)
member.summary: If CapAutoScan is TRUE, this command will stop the operation of the scanner’s automatic feeder. No other action is taken.

member.name: T:NTwain.Triplets.SetupFileXfer
member.summary: Represents .

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.SetupFileXfer.Get(NTwain.Data.TWSetupFileXfer@)
member.summary: Returns information about the file into which the Source has or will put the acquired image or audio data.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.SetupFileXfer.GetDefault(NTwain.Data.TWSetupFileXfer@)
member.summary: Returns information for the default image or audio file.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.SetupFileXfer.Reset(NTwain.Data.TWSetupFileXfer@)
member.summary: Resets the current file information to the image or audio default file information and returns that default information.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.SetupFileXfer.Set(NTwain.Data.TWSetupFileXfer)
member.summary: Sets the file transfer information for the next file transfer. The application is responsible for verifying that the specified file name is valid and that the file either does not currently exist (in which case, the Source is to create the file), or that the existing file is available for opening and read/write operations. The application should also assure that the file format it is requesting can be provided by the Source

member.name: T:NTwain.Triplets.UserInterface
member.summary: Represents .

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.UserInterface.DisableDS(NTwain.Data.TWUserInterface)
member.summary: This operation causes the Source’s user interface, if displayed during the EnableDS operation, to be lowered. The Source is returned to State 4, where capability negotiation can again occur. The application can invoke this operation either because it wants to shut down the current session, or in response to the Source "posting" a CloseDSReq event to it. Rarely, the application may need to close the Source because an error condition was detected.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.UserInterface.EnableDS(NTwain.Data.TWUserInterface)
member.summary: Enables the DS.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.UserInterface.EnableDSUIOnly(NTwain.Data.TWUserInterface)
member.summary: This operation is used by applications that wish to display the source user interface to allow the user to manipulate the sources current settings for DPI, paper size, etc. but not acquire an image.

member.name: T:NTwain.Triplets.XferGroup
member.summary: Represents .

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.XferGroup.Get(NTwain.Data.DataGroups@)
member.summary: Returns the Data Group (the type of data) for the upcoming transfer. The Source is required to only supply one of the DGs specified in the SupportedGroups field of origin.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.XferGroup.Set(NTwain.Data.DataGroups)
member.summary: The transfer group determines the kind of data being passed from the Source to the Application. By default a TWAIN Source must default to DG_IMAGE. Currently the only other data group supported is DG_AUDIO, which is a feature supported by some digital cameras.

member.summary: Represents .

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.GrayResponse.Reset(NTwain.Data.TWGrayResponse@)
member.summary: The Reset operation causes the Source to use its "identity response curve." The identity curve causes no change in the values of the captured data when it is applied.

member.summary: This operation causes the Source to transform any grayscale data according to the response curve specified.

member.name: T:NTwain.Triplets.IccProfile
member.summary: Represents .

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.IccProfile.Get(NTwain.Data.TWMemory@)
member.summary: This operation provides the application with the ICC profile associated with the image which is about to be transferred (state 6) or is being transferred (state 7).

member.name: T:NTwain.Triplets.ImageFileXfer
member.summary: Represents .

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.ImageFileXfer.Get
member.summary: This operation is used to initiate the transfer of an image from the Source to the application via the disk-file transfer mechanism. It causes the transfer to begin.

member.name: T:NTwain.Triplets.ImageInfo
member.summary: Represents .

member.name: T:NTwain.Triplets.ImageLayout
member.summary: Represents .

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.ImageLayout.Get(NTwain.Data.TWImageLayout@)
member.summary: Gets both the size and placement of the image on the scanner. The coordinates on the scanner and the extents of the image are expressed in the unit of measure currently negotiated for ICAP_UNITS (default is inches).

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.ImageLayout.GetDefault(NTwain.Data.TWImageLayout@)
member.summary: returns the default information on the layout of an image. This is the size and position of the image that will be acquired from the Source if the acquisition is started with the Source (and the device it is controlling) in its power-on state (for instance, most flatbed scanners will capture the entire bed).

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.ImageLayout.Reset(NTwain.Data.TWImageLayout@)
member.summary: This operation sets the image layout information for the next transfer to its default settings.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.ImageLayout.Set(NTwain.Data.TWImageLayout)
member.summary: This operation sets the layout for the next image transfer. This allows the application to specify the physical area to be acquired during the next image transfer (for instance, a frame-based application would pass to the Source the size of the frame the user selected within the application—the helpful Source would present a selection region already sized to match the layout frame size).

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.ImageMemFileXfer.Get(NTwain.Data.TWImageMemXfer)
member.summary: This operation is used to initiate the transfer of an image from the Source to the application via the Memory-File transfer mechanism.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.ImageMemXfer.Get(NTwain.Data.TWImageMemXfer)
member.summary: This operation is used to initiate the transfer of an image from the Source to the application via the Buffered Memory transfer mechanism.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.ImageNativeXfer.Get(System.IntPtr@)
member.summary: Causes the transfer of an image’s data from the Source to the application, via the Native transfer mechanism, to begin. The resulting data is stored in main memory in a single block. The data is stored in Picture (PICT) format on the Macintosh and as a device-independent bitmap (DIB) under Microsoft Windows. The size of the image that can be transferred is limited to the size of the memory block that can be allocated by the Source.

member.name: T:NTwain.Triplets.JpegCompression
member.summary: Represents .

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.JpegCompression.Get(NTwain.Data.TWJpegCompression@)
member.summary: Causes the Source to return the parameters that will be used during the compression of data using the JPEG algorithms.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.JpegCompression.GetDefault(NTwain.Data.TWJpegCompression@)
member.summary: Causes the Source to return the power-on default values applied to JPEG-compressed data transfers.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.JpegCompression.Reset(NTwain.Data.TWJpegCompression@)
member.summary: Return the Source to using its power-on default values for JPEG-compressed transfers.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.JpegCompression.Set(NTwain.Data.TWJpegCompression)
member.summary: Allows the application to configure the compression parameters to be used on all future JPEGcompressed transfers during the current session. The application should have already established that the requested values are supported by the Source.

member.name: T:NTwain.Triplets.Palette8
member.summary: Represents .

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.Palette8.Get(NTwain.Data.TWPalette8@)
member.summary: This operation causes the Source to report its current palette information.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.Palette8.GetDefault(NTwain.Data.TWPalette8@)
member.summary: This operation causes the Source to report its power-on default palette.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.Palette8.Reset(NTwain.Data.TWPalette8@)
member.summary: This operation causes the Source to dispose of any current palette it has and to use its default palette for the next palette transfer.

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.Palette8.Set(NTwain.Data.TWPalette8)
member.summary: This operation requests that the Source adopt the specified palette for use with all subsequent palette transfers. The application should be careful to supply a palette that matches the bit depth of the Source. The Source is not required to adopt this palette. The application should be careful to check the return value from this operation.

member.name: T:NTwain.Triplets.RgbResponse
member.summary: Represents .

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.RgbResponse.Reset(NTwain.Data.TWRgbResponse@)
member.summary: Causes the Source to use its "identity" response curves for future RGB transfers. The identity curve causes no change in the values of the captured data when it is applied. (Note that resetting the curves for RGB data does not reset any curves for other pixel types).

member.name: M:NTwain.Triplets.RgbResponse.Set(NTwain.Data.TWRgbResponse)
member.summary: Causes the Source to transform any RGB data according to the response curves specified by the application.
